editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

Full documentation of the original data capture process is available from the Text Creation Partnership web site. All versions of the texts are now archived and freely available for download. See the TCP Download FAQ for detailed information. The TEI P5 versions are also freely available from the TCP Github repository.

div.p: ¶ Here after foloweth twoo fruitfull and godly praiers / the one in laude and prayse of the trinitie / and the other desiryng grace to with stande the feare of death.
❧ Imprynted at London / in Paules ❧ churcheyarde by Rycharde Lante / and Rycharde Bankes. Anno Domini, M,D,XLV.

lg.l: O Holy God of dredfull maiestie
Verely one / three / and three in one
Who in angels serue whose werkes all creaturs be
Whiche heuen and earth / directest all a lone
We thee beseche good lorde / with whofull mone
Spare vs wretches / and washe a waye our gylt
That wee bee not / by thy iust anger spilt
❧ In straight ballance / of rigorus iudgement
If thou shouldest / our synnes ponder and waye
Who able wer / to beare thy punishement
The whole engyn / of all this worlde I saie
The engyn / that endure shall for aie
With suche examinacion / maie not stande
Space of one moment / in thy angry hande.
❧ Who is not borne / in synne originall
Who dooth not actuall synne / in sundry wise
But thou art he good lorde / that sparest all
With piteouse mercie / temperyng iustice
For as thou dooest / to vs rewardes deuise
Aboue our merites / so dooest thou dispence
Thy punishment / far vnder our offence.
❧ More is thy mercie lorde / then all our syn
To geue theim / that vnworthy bee
More goodly is / and more mercie therin
How bee it / worthie inough are thei perdie
Bee thei neuer so vnworthie / whom that he
List to accept / where so euer be taketh
Whom he vnworthy fyndeth / worthie maketh
❧ Wherfore good lorde / that aye mercifull art
Vnto thy grace / and soueraigne dignitee
Wee sely wretches / crye with wofull harte
Our synnes forget / and our malignitee
With piteous yies / of thy benignitee
Frendly loke on vs / once thyne owne we bee
Seruauntes or synners / whether it liketh thee
❧ Synners / if thou our cryme beholde certain
The cryme / the werke / of our vncurtese mynde
But if thy giftes / thou beholde again
Thy giftes noble / wonderfull and kynde
Thou shalt vs then / the same persones fynde
Whiche are to thee and haue been / by long space
Seruauntes by nature / children by thy grace.
❧ But this thy goodned / wryngeth vs alas
For we whom grace / had made thy children dere
Are made thy gylty folke / by our trespas
Synne hath vs gilty made / this many a yere
But let thy grace / thy grace that hath no pere
Of our offence / surmounten all the preace
That in our synne / thy honor maie encreace.
Hor though thy goodnes / through thy mightie power
Mate otherwise appeare sufficiently
As thynges / whiche thy creatures euery oure
With one voyce / declare and testify
Thy goodnes yet / thy syngular mercy
Thy petious harte / thy gracious indulgence
Nothyng so clerely sheweth / as our offence.
What but our syn / hath shewed ye mighty loue
Whiche able was / thy dredfull maiestie
To drawe downe in to earth / from heuen aboue
And crucifie god / that we pore wretches wee
Should from our filthy synnes / clensed bee
With bloode and water / of thyne owne syde
That stremed / from thy blessed woundes wyde.
❧ Why loue and pitie / thus O heuenly kyng
Our ciuill maketh matter / of thy goodnes
O loue O pitte / our welth aye well prouidyng
O goodnes seruyng / thy seruauntes in destres
O loue O pitie / well nigh now thankeles
O goodnes mightie / gracious and wyse
And yet almoste vanquished with our vise.
❧ Graunt good lorde / suche hete into my hart
That into this loue of thyne / mate bee egall,
Graunt me from satans seruice to estart
With whō me ruith / so long to haue been thrall
Graunte me good lorde / and creator of all
The flame to quenche / of all synnefull desire
And in thy loue / set all my harte a fyre.
❧ That when the iournay / of this dedly life
My sely ghoste / hath finished and thence
Departe muste / with out his fleshely wife
A loue into his lordes high presence
He maye the fynde / O well of indulgence
In thy lordeshippe / not as a lorde but rather
As a very louyng and tender father.

div.head: A prayer against the fere of death.

lg.l: O Lorde Iesu / the onely health of men liuyng
And life euerlastyng / of thē whiche faithfull dy
I moste wretched synner / doo giue to the praisyng
And wholy submit myself / to thy greate mercy
Nothyng can bee compared / vnto thy pity
None truly can perishe / that putteth their trust in ye
wherfore moste louyng lord / haue mercy now on me
Haue mercy & pity on me / I say / moste merciful lord
whiche hūbly beseche the / to giue me now thy grace
That I may now willyngly / forsake al frail discord
Pertainyng to this life / now graūt me tyme & space
Here to dispise this fleshe / that I maye se thy face
I trust moste blessed lorde / in thy compassion
More clerely for to rise / in my resurreccion.
❧ O mercifull Iesu / I humbly crye to the
that ye wilt by thy grace / make sure & strōg my soule
Against the fere of death / my flesh sore troubleth me
That frō temptacions / my corporall yies may roule
And that I maye se the / with the yies of my soule
This mercifully here me / auert from me thy sworde
Of thy indignacion / accordyng to thy worde.
❧ Lorde vnder the buckler / of mercy thou me kepe
Like as thou hast preserued / thy holy marters all
whō thou madest ouercome / the ferce tormentes depe
Of their greuous death / & broughte thē out of thrall
That I maye haue like grace / to the I hartely call
Haue mercy on my soule / when it passeth my boby
Which of his own kind / worketh nought but misery
❧ I acknowledge my self / that I am destytute
Of all sucker and help / nothyng I worke but synne
Of my selfe good lorde / but yet I make my sute
Puttyng my trust in the / at length heuen to wynde
For my confidence / onely good lorde is in
The my lorde and sauiour / Iesu my saluacion
By the merites of thy death / and of thy passion.
No merites nor good workes / now of myself I haue
Before ye to knowledge / wherfore my flesh doth quake
But only it lieth in the good lorde / my soule to saue
Not able I am to ye / for my synnes amēdes to make
Through thy mercy by faith / yet in thy blod I take
A perfect hope & trust / thou wilt not impute my syne
But accept into thy grace / through ye heuē to winne
Thou mercifull lorde / which borne was for my sake
And for me a synner / great tormentes & great payne
Thou hast in erth here take / frō sine me for to wake
To hange vpon the crosse / thy selfe didst not abstain
To haue thy syde wide opē / no smart ye didst refrain
To shed thy precious blode / ye barest to mā such loue
Non might bide such smart / for mā this wil I proue
Make all these thy paynes / good lorde to profet me
Let thy most precious blode / my soule & body clense
Let the smart passion / whiche thou suffred on tre
Satisfy for my synnes / I cannot make no mense
Of my self good lorde / so opprest I am with senes
Let thy righteousnes / my vnrighteousnes hyde
Washe from me my synnes / that I from the not slide
❧ Gyue me grace O lorde / I wauer not in faith
But to be firme and stable / in the O liuyng god
My hope and saluacion / thus the scriptures saith
This fleshe do not cōfoūde me / ye I shuld tast thy rod
That my loue and charite / to the bee not doune trod
Finally the weakenes / of this my fleshely breth
Ouercome be not / at any tyme with the fere of death
☞ Graūt me o mercifull lorde / as my trust is in the
That when death shutteth vp / the yies of my body
The yies of my soule / to the liftned maye be
By true faith and hope / to liue eternally
where as is no discorde / no payne nor misery
But euerlastyng peace / whiche no toungue can tell
But euer shall induer / for euer I know right well
This when death shall take / away my toūge & voyce
yet my harte maye crye / and saie to the O lorde
In thy holy handes / now let my soule reioyce
Like a louyng father / accordyng to thy worde
Let not my soule suffer / the ier of thy sworde
This bothe soule and body / to the I doo commende
To whom bee honor and prayse / euer without ende.
